properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham.
  • Moderate flooding continuing along Murray River at Barham
  • Minor flooding occurring at Corowa and Torrumbarry Weir  
  • River levels at Torrumbarry Weir have reached the minor flood level during Friday morning. 
  • Downstream, moderate flooding is likely to continue into next week at Barham.
  • Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham: Minor to moderate flooding is occurring along the Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham.   
  • The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is currently at 7.30 metres and rising slowly, with minor flooding. 
  • The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is likely to remain around the minor flood level (7.30 metres) during the remainder of Friday and over the weekend.   
  • The Murray River at Barham is currently at 5.82 metres (above the moderate flood level of 5.80 metres) and rising slowly. 
  • The Murray River at Barham is likely to reach around 5.85 metres over the weekend and into next week, with moderate flooding.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services. 
  • Check the Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/get-into-nature/safety-in-nature/changed-conditions-and-closures) for park closures. 
  • This flood will likely be contained within the forested areas.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/07/2023 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - RIVERINE FLOOD - Avoid the Flooded Area
Incident Location: Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham
Issue Date: Saturday 15 July 2023, 01:11 pm
Next Update: Monday 17 July 2023, 01:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/29826/moreinfo

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham.
- Moderate flooding continuing along Murray River at Barham
- Minor flooding occurring at Corowa and Torrumbarry Weir  
- River levels at Torrumbarry Weir have reached the minor flood level during Friday morning. 
- Downstream, moderate flooding is likely to continue into next week at Barham.
- Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham:  Minor to moderate flooding is occurring along the Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham.    
- The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is currently at 7.30 metres and rising slowly, with minor flooding. 
- The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is likely to remain around the minor flood level (7.30 metres) during the remainder of Friday and over the weekend.    
- The Murray River at Barham is currently at 5.82 metres (above the moderate flood level of 5.80 metres) and rising slowly. 
- The Murray River at Barham is likely to reach around 5.85 metres over the weekend and into next week, with moderate flooding.


Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT BANDIANA 
Minor flooding has been ongoing at Bandiana over the last week and may continue over the weekend.
No significant rainfall has been recorded in the past few days across the Kiewa River catchment. 
No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Kiewa River at Bandiana 
The Kiewa River at Bandiana is currently at 2.88 metres and falling slowly, above the minor flood level (2.80 m). The Kiewa River at Bandiana may remain above the minor flood level (2.80 m) over the weekend.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/07/2023 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran, Marlo.

  • Due to a whale carcass that remains on the beach, there could be an increase in shark activity reported at Point Ricardo.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • This is an update, replacing the Advice issued on 23 June.
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • Victorian Fisheries Authority is assisting wildlife officers and park rangers with the management of the whale carcass.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 18/07/2023 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - DANGEROUS ANIMAL - Avoid the Area
Incident Location: Point Ricardo
Issue Date: Thursday 13 July 2023, 12:20 pm
Next Update: Tuesday 18 July 2023, 12:30 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/29814/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran, Marlo.

- Due to a whale carcass that remains on the beach, there could be an increase in shark activity reported at Point Ricardo. 
- A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
- While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area. 
- This is an update, replacing the Advice issued on 23 June.


Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT COROWA    

Minor flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Corowa where the river level remains around a prolonged minor flood peak

Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal: 
Minor flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Corowa. 
River levels downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal are expected to remain elevated into next week.   

The Murray River at Corowa is currently at 4.84 metres and steady around a prolonged minor flood peak. 
The Murray River at Corowa is likely to remain above the minor flood level (4.60 m) during the remainder of Friday and over the weekend.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/07/2023 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
